case_vignette: A 28-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department after a window he was installing fell on him. The patient complains of left ocular pain, blurred vision, and obscured lower portion of the left visual field. The patient’s vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 140/80 mm Hg, heart rate 88/min, respiratory rate 14/min, and temperature 36.9℃ (98.4℉). On physical examination, he has multiple superficial lacerations on his face, arms, and legs. Examination of his right eye shows a superficial upper eyelid laceration. Examination of the left eye shows conjunctival hyperemia, peaked pupil, iridial asymmetry, hyphema, and vitreous hemorrhage. The fundus is hard to visualize due to the vitreous hemorrhage. The visual acuity is 20/25 in the right eye and difficult to evaluate in the left.
question: Which  is a proper step to undertake in the diagnosis and management of this patient?
correct_ans: systemic administration of vancomycin and levofloxacin

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I'm experiencing pain in my left eye, blurred vision, and I can't see the lower part of my vision on the left side.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
These symptoms started after the window fell on me today.
Did you lose consciousness at any point after the incident?
No, I did not lose consciousness.
Do you have any other injuries or areas of pain besides the left eye?
Is there any redness or bleeding in or around your eye?
Yes, there's redness and my left eye has some bleeding inside of it.
Have you experienced any similar eye problems or injuries in the past?
No, I have not had any similar eye problems or injuries before.
Do you have any known allergies or are you currently taking any medication?
I don't have any known allergies and I'm not on any medication.
Is there a history of glaucoma or other eye diseases in your family?
I'm not aware of any family history of glaucoma or other eye diseases.
Have you noticed any flashing lights, floaters or changes in eye pressure?
No, I haven't noticed any flashing lights, floaters, or changes in eye pressure.

Given the history of trauma to the eye, you should seek immediate medical attention as you may require an in-person examination and possibly imaging to rule out serious conditions like a retinal detachment or globe rupture, among others.

**Final Diagnosis:** Traumatic eye injury with possible hyphema or orbital fracture.

These symptoms started after a window fell on the patient. The patient did not lose consciousness and has redness and bleeding inside the left eye. The patient has not experienced any similar eye problems or injuries before, and has no known allergies or current medication. There is no family history of glaucoma or other eye diseases, and the patient has not experienced flashing lights, floaters, or changes in eye pressure.
trial_0.vignette_mcq: Ultrasound examination of the left eye.
trial_0.vignette_frq: This patient should be urgently evaluated by an ophthalmologist, and a CT scan of the orbits should be performed to exclude ocular penetration and orbital fracture. Initial management should also include elevating the head of the bed to 30-45 degrees, providing analgesia, antiemetic medication to avoid vomiting and increased intraocular pressure, and initiating treatment with topical steroids and cycloplegic agents under ophthalmology guidance.
trial_0.multiturn_mcq: Final Diagnosis: Traumatic hyphema and orbital blowout fracture.
trial_0.multiturn_frq: **Final Diagnosis:** Trauma to the eye with possible hyphema and partial visual field loss.

trial_0.singleturn_frq: Final Diagnosis: Possible left eye retinal detachment or ocular migraine. Immediate referral to an ophthalmologist is necessary.
